title: Annona (mythology)
text:
In <a href="Religion%20in%20ancient%20Rome">ancient Roman religion</a>, Annona (Latin <a href="wikt%3Aannona">annōna</a> “corn, grain; means of subsistence”, from <a href="wikt%3Aannus">annus</a> "year") is the divine <a href="anthropomorphism">personification</a> of the <a href="grain%20supply%20to%20the%20city%20of%20Rome">grain supply to the city of Rome</a>. She is closely connected to the goddess <a href="Ceres%20%28mythology%29">Ceres</a>, with whom she is often depicted in <a href="Roman%20art">art</a>.
Annona, often as Annona <a href="Augustus%20%28honorific%29">Augusti</a>, was a creation of <a href="Imperial%20cult%20%28ancient%20Rome%29">Imperial religious propaganda</a>, manifested in <a href="iconography">iconography</a> and cult practice. She is presented as a <a href="theophany">theophany</a> of the <a href="Roman%20emperor">emperor</a>'s power to care for his people through the provision of grain. Annona thus lacked <a href="Roman%20mythology">narrative mythology</a> or a <a href="Religion%20in%20ancient%20Rome">tradition of devotion</a> in the <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a>, but once established as part of <a href="Imperial%20cult%20%28ancient%20Rome%29">Imperial cult</a>, she was the recipient of <a href="votum">dedications and votive offerings</a> from private individuals motivated by gratitude or the seeking of favor.
Imperial cult.
In the propaganda of <a href="Claudius">Claudius</a>, the cult of "Ceres Augusta" made explicit the divine power that lay in the Imperial provision of the "annona", the grain supply to the city. Annona Augusti appears on <a href="Roman%20currency">coins</a> late in the reign of <a href="Nero">Nero</a>, when the Cult of Virtues came into prominence in the wake of the <a href="Pisonian%20conspiracy">Pisonian conspiracy</a>. She embodied two of the material benefits of <a href="Roman%20Empire">Imperial rule</a>, along with Securitas Augusti, "Augustan Security," and often appeared as part of a pair with Ceres. On Neronian coinage, Ceres, Annona, and <a href="Abundantia">Abundantia</a> ("Abundance") were closely associated.
Annona also appears on coins issued under <a href="Vespasian">Vespasian</a>, where along with other Virtues she represents the restoration of confidence in the <a href="principate">principate</a>, and on the coinage of <a href="Titus">Titus</a>, <a href="Domitian">Domitian</a>, <a href="Trajan">Trajan</a>, <a href="Hadrian">Hadrian</a>, <a href="Antoninus%20Pius">Antoninus Pius</a>, and <a href="Septimius%20Severus">Septimius Severus</a>. She was a particular favorite in Trajan's propaganda, which sought to portray his reign as a renewal and a prosperous new era for humanity; hence Annona often appears with a symbolic child. In the context of Trajanic politics, Annona represented Rome's grain independence from its traditional supplier <a href="Egypt%20%28Roman%20province%29">Egypt</a>.
Iconography.
Annona is typically depicted with a <a href="cornucopia">cornucopia</a> (horn of plenty) in her arm, and a ship's prow in the background, alluding to the transport of grain into the harbor of Rome. On coins, she frequently stands between a <a href="Ancient%20Roman%20units%20of%20measurement%23Dry%20measures">modius</a> (grain-measure) and the prow of a <a href="galley">galley</a>, with ears of grain in one hand and a cornucopia in the other; sometimes she holds a <a href="rudder">rudder</a> or an <a href="anchor">anchor</a>.
Namesake.
The crater <a href="Annona%20%28crater%29">Annona</a> in the southern hemisphere of the dwarf planet <a href="Ceres%20%28dwarf%20planet%29">Ceres</a> was named after this deity.
